docs.snippet: Subbing for an Old Friend     Annie Ross, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street in Manhattan, (212) 533-7902. Annie Ross, the virtuoso scat singer of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, the celebrated vocal trio of the 1950's, is making her fir...
docs.lead_paragraph: Subbing for an Old Friend Annie Ross, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street in Manhattan, (212) 533-7902. Annie Ross, the virtuoso scat singer of Lambert, Hendricks and Ross, the celebrated vocal trio of the 1950's, is making her first appearance in New York this weekend since she sang in the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel two years ago. Since then, she has been appearing on the stage in London, on television and in films, but not in nightclubs. She works out twice a week with a vocal coach, however, so when she was asked to step in as a last-minute replacement at Fat Tuesday's for Jon Hendricks, a partner of 30 years ago, she was prepared. Her shows tonight, tomorrow and Sunday are at 8 and 10. There is a $12.50 cover charge and a $7.50 minimum. Walter Norris's Pianism

docs.snippet: No Deal on 'Assassins'    "Assassins," the Stephen Sondheim-John Weidman musical about Presidential assassins, directed by Jerry Zaks, is not opening on Broadway or anywhere else this season. Despite reports that the show, whose limited run at Pla...
docs.lead_paragraph: No Deal on 'Assassins' "Assassins," the Stephen Sondheim-John Weidman musical about Presidential assassins, directed by Jerry Zaks, is not opening on Broadway or anywhere else this season. Despite reports that the show, whose limited run at Playwrights Horizons ended on Feb. 16, would move to the Golden Theater, negotiations between the Shubert Organization and David Geffen, the Hollywood movie- and record-industry executive and occasional Broadway producer, broke off this week.

docs.snippet: Nils Gaup's "Shipwrecked," presented by Walt Disney Pictures, is the kind of innocent live-action adventure movie the Disney people used to make before they turned their attention to adult audiences.   The film is an adaptation of the Norwegian no...
docs.lead_paragraph: Nils Gaup's "Shipwrecked," presented by Walt Disney Pictures, is the kind of innocent live-action adventure movie the Disney people used to make before they turned their attention to adult audiences. The film is an adaptation of the Norwegian novelist O. V. Falck-Ytter's "Haakon Haakonsen," published in 1873. It should be noted that this is eight years before the appearance of the first installments of Robert Louis Stevenson's "Treasure Island," which it recalls, if dimly.

docs.snippet: The war's swift end has left soldiers and marines relieved that there were few American casualties, skeptical of Saddam Hussein's intentions and disappointed that they never got to test their mettle in battle.    Despite Baghdad's announcement tha...
docs.lead_paragraph: The war's swift end has left soldiers and marines relieved that there were few American casualties, skeptical of Saddam Hussein's intentions and disappointed that they never got to test their mettle in battle. Despite Baghdad's announcement that Iraq would honor the United Nations resolutions and begin a cease-fire, American troops interviewed in Kuwait and Saudi Arabia question Iraqi motives.

headline.main: Some of the Americans Feel Test of Mettle Was Too Easy

byline.original: By CHRIS HEDGES, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: On Sunset Boulevard, huge billboards proclaim that "Goodfellas" has been nominated for six Academy Awards and "Awakenings" for three. At home, the nearly 5,000 performers, technicians and executives who actually select the Oscar winners have once ...
docs.lead_paragraph: On Sunset Boulevard, huge billboards proclaim that "Goodfellas" has been nominated for six Academy Awards and "Awakenings" for three. At home, the nearly 5,000 performers, technicians and executives who actually select the Oscar winners have once again been besieged with promotional brochures, videocassettes and screening and party invitations, all submitted "for your consideration." For most of the moviegoing public, the Academy Awards are a one-night affair. But across Hollywood, a long and clamorous campaign annually sets the stage for the carefully orchestrated television ceremony. Drawing on everything from technology to emotional appeals, the competitors are once again pulling out all the stops in their efforts to take home a statuette when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences announces the winners on March 25.

headline.main: Tactics in the Annual Campaign for Oscars

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: MOTION PICTURE ARTS AND SCIENCES, ACADEMY OF

byline.original: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: WITH a mixture of glamour and gravity, the fashion industry gave out its annual awards Monday night. The black-tie affair at the Metropolitan Museum of Art began with cocktails and a huge crush of designers, models and celebrities in a frenzy of s...
docs.lead_paragraph: WITH a mixture of glamour and gravity, the fashion industry gave out its annual awards Monday night. The black-tie affair at the Metropolitan Museum of Art began with cocktails and a huge crush of designers, models and celebrities in a frenzy of sequins and flashbulbs. The awards given by the Council of Fashion Designers of America, a trade group of about 140 designers, are to Seventh Avenue what the Academy Awards are to Hollywood. They honor excellence, achievement and a talent for self-promotion, as well as providing a deluxe opportunity for working the room. For fashion executives who worked late and went directly to the museum, it was a hard day's night.

headline.main: Glamour and Glad-Handing At High-Fashion's Awards

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: COUNCIL OF FASHION DESIGNERS OF AMERICA

docs.snippet: IT stands like some child's sweet-tooth fantasy, a merry-go-round loaded with jumbo strawberry shortcakes, giant chocolate layer cakes, lemon meringue pies so tall they defy gravity, gooey banana cream pies, pools of coconut custard and cheesecake...
docs.lead_paragraph: IT stands like some child's sweet-tooth fantasy, a merry-go-round loaded with jumbo strawberry shortcakes, giant chocolate layer cakes, lemon meringue pies so tall they defy gravity, gooey banana cream pies, pools of coconut custard and cheesecakes as thick as bowling balls. " This is advertising," said Jimmy Kaloidis, owner of the Georgia Diner in Elmhurst, Queens, pointing to the revolving dessert case that guards the entrance to his restaurant.

headline.main: Greek Diners, Where Anything Is Possible

docs.snippet: Cornelia and Michael Bessie, who have published books under their own name at HarperCollins since 1981, will end their relationship with the publishing house by the end of June. No reason was given for the split, which was announced by HarperColli...
docs.lead_paragraph: Cornelia and Michael Bessie, who have published books under their own name at HarperCollins since 1981, will end their relationship with the publishing house by the end of June. No reason was given for the split, which was announced by HarperCollins last week. Both Mr. Bessie and George Craig, president and chief executive of HarperCollins, said the decision had been arrived at by mutual consent.

docs.snippet: The nomination of the Chinese film "Judou" this month for an Academy Award might have been a tremendous triumph for a nation that has long sought respect from the West. Instead, in a move that says much about the state of the arts in China today, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: The nomination of the Chinese film "Judou" this month for an Academy Award might have been a tremendous triumph for a nation that has long sought respect from the West. Instead, in a move that says much about the state of the arts in China today, the Government has tried to suppress the film and withdraw it from consideration. "Judou," a beautifully filmed tragedy portraying a dye factory and the family that runs it, has become the centerpiece of a bitter drama about politics and art in China. If "Judou" is a symbol of the best in Chinese films, the Government's treatment of the film and of the Oscar nomination is a stark measure of the cultural repression that continues to haunt Chinese intellectuals and artists some 20 months after the 1989 Tiananmen crackdown.

headline.main: China Fights an Academy Award Nomination

byline.original: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times
